blocks.text: Referring to the last example, note that the power of e is exactly the same after differentiation as before; the factor e multiplies the I.V. in the original function, and therefore it occurs as a constant multiplier after differentiation; also the constant factors remain.
If C₁ = C₂ = C and C₁ and C₂ are electrical capacities, then there is a rate of change of the circuit and t is a time, thus the time rate of change of the circuit is given by
i.e., the rate of decrease of the current when the impressed E.M.F. is removed is proportional to the current at that time.
Before further evaluating the example, take the case where R = 15 Ω, C = 18.75 μF, t = 1.5 s, and I = 4.5 A.

Per second, whereas the actual current is only 2 A.
The expressions of e and c are partial forms of the more general exponential forms and are used to differentiate which may be represented by either of two methods:
